etymologies: Middle English (as a verb in the sense ‘rear up’, also used as a heraldic term): from Old French ramper ‘creep, crawl’, of unknown origin. Sense 1 of the noun dates from the late 18th century

definitions: a slope or inclined plane for joining two different levels, as at the entrance or between floors of a building
shortDefinitions: sloping surface joining two different levels, as at entrance or between floors of building

definitions: a movable set of steps for entering or leaving an aircraft.
shortDefinitions: movable set of steps for entering or leaving aircraft

definitions: an inclined road leading onto or off a main road or highway
shortDefinitions: inclined slip road leading on to or off main road or motorway

definitions: an upward bend in a stair rail.
an electrical waveform in which the voltage increases or decreases linearly with time
shortDefinitions: electrical waveform in which voltage increases or decreases linearly with time

examples.text: we have purposefully ramped the entrance to make it easier access

definitions: drive up the price of (a company's shares) in order to gain a financial advantage

examples.text: they're trying to ramp the share price
a rule against share price ramping which forbids a broker to account for more than 30 per cent of trading in a share

definitions: (of an animal) rear up on its hind legs in a threatening posture

examples.text: they roared and ramped in cages

shortDefinitions: (of animal) rear up on its hind legs in threatening posture

examples.text: an awful beast ramping about the woods and fields

definitions: (of a plant) grow or climb luxuriantly

examples.text: ivy ramped over the flower beds

definitions: (of an electrical waveform) increase or decrease voltage linearly with time

examples.text: the integrated circuit's output then ramps in the negative direction

shortDefinitions: (of electrical waveform) increase or decrease voltage linearly with time
